title: D∙E∙P∙T
content:
Does anybody know which font they  
used for this?

Would love to know.

Grtz Chris

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [dept.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20140117164141/http:/typophile.com/files/dept.gif) | 4.04 KB |
author: Chris82

comments.content:
Look at the height of the horizontal serifs versus the width of the vertical serifs. I'm guessing this was a font with very thin horizontal strokes, squooshed to make it appear taller.

- Lex

Lex, I think you're right. I tried it with a normal serif font at 300% the normal height, and got something very similar in shape. I wanted to try it with Perpetua, but it wasn't handy. (I think you need a typeface with a P whose bowl droops a bit after leaving the stem.)

If you don't want to play such games, [Peplum](http://web.archive.org/web/20140117164141/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/peplum/peplum/testdrive.html?s=D+E+P+T&p=72) is similar 'off the shelf'.

- Mike Yanega

Thanks guys for the info.  
You helped me a lot.

[www.futuredesign.nl](http://web.archive.org/web/20140117164141/http:/www.futuredesign.nl/ "www.futuredesign.nl")
